field_edited_text.value:
IV. The Research Phase

1. Preliminary Survey

Numerous studies and documents prepared in
the previous five years were examined as
possible sources of background material. A
total of 69 reports, brochures and data sheets
and more than 40 maps--all prepared for
various agencies in Baltimore--were

examined to provide a general framework for
understanding the physical, social and
economic forces which had influenced the
development of these three study areas.

It was found that, physically, the three areas
have several characteristics in common, as well
as a few significant differences.

Once important as shopping areas for
residential developments on the fringe of the
growing city, they are now showing signs of
their age. There are large numbers of
deteriorated buildings which are functionally
inefficient and difficult to adapt to today’s
tastes. Ground-floor stores with apartments
above are common, often stretching for several
blocks along major streets or extending for
several blocks in several directions from a main
corner.

The shopping areas are small centers in a large
region, centered in Baltimore. Baltimore is the
center of a five-county region and its
downtown area serves this larger area as well as
the city itself.

The three areas studied each contain a public
market, a common structure divided into stalls
where vendors sell their wares, usually food.
Three other older shopping areas of the 17 such
areas identified by the city also contain a public
market.

The three shopping areas are patronized by
residents of surrounding neighborhoods who
can conveniently walk there to buy food, drugs,
clothing and furniture, as well as by a steadily
increasing number of shoppers who come by
private or public transportation. In that sense,
they serve as centers of a community. They also
have a focus as a place where people in the area
go to use public transportation. All three areas
are well served by public transportation and
also act as transfer points where people can
change mode of travel or change direction,
from one bus to another.

2. Survey and Analysis

a. Building survey

A detailed structural survey was made of all
buildings in the three study areas. A survey
form was designed to measure factors
contributing to deterioration and buildings
were classified into four general categories:

Standard

Deficient - 1st degree
Deficient - 2nd degree
Substandard

The categories were related as much as possible
to possible rehabilitation efforts in the future.
Structures requiring little or no rehabilitation
were rated as standard. Those requiring
rehabilitation so extensive as to be prohibitive
in cost were classified as substandard. In
between were the deficient buildings: Those
which could be easily rehabilitated and those
requiring substantial rehabilitation.

A manual was prepared and training sessions
held for city building inspectors who carried
out the survey, to insure that buildings were
evaluated on a uniform basis. Information
obtained was transferred to data processing
cards and analyzed on the basis of land uses
found in each study area and also on a
block-by-block basis within each area. The
findings of the structural survey are
summarized in the following table.

Analysis of Structural Survey Data

Summary of Findings

Pennsylvania Monument Light
Avenue Street Street
MO, % No. % No. %
Number of
Structures 470 213 352
Standard
Striebes 15 32% 48225% 42 119%
Deficient -
1st Degree 128 27.2%116 54.5% 95 27.0%
Deficient -
2nd Degree 66 14.0% 12 56% 55 15.6%

Sub-
Standard 261 55.5% 37 17.4% 160 455%

b. General Surveys ]

An evaluation was made of factors affecting the
environment of the three areas, including
exterior building condition, level of street and
sidewalk maintenance, nuisance uses, presence
of adequate utilities, condition of rear yards
and such favorable features as trees and
plantings.

Available city reports were reviewed and a
limited field inspection made to evaluate land
use, building conditions and community
facilities. Street and traffic plans were reviewed
and an evaluation made of traffic and its impact
on the areas. Existing parking facilities were
evaluated in terms of availability, type, location
and appearance.

Property owners in the three areas have made
only limited improvements to their premises
over the years. The resulting deterioration has
left the areas blighted and functionally
inefficient.

There is a high incidence of vacant land and
floor space, and property values have not
increased at a level experienced by other parts
of the city. In fact, tax assessments from 1953
to 1963, including changes in valuation
resulting from demolition and new
construction, showed a decrease in the
seventeen older areas of 6%, while showing an
increase of 27% in the remainder of the city.

Most streets in the three areas are congested,
and there is a lack of parking space for shoppers
and loading space for vehicles servicing the
businesses in the areas. This makes it difficult
for pedestrians to move about safely and
conveniently.

There is a distinct lack of amenities for people
in the area, such as open spaces for resting and
observation, and little, if any, landscaping. In
addition, the visual effect of signs, traffic
signals, street furniture, storefronts and
advertising combine to present an unattractive
scene to the shopper or passerby.

c. Market Studies

Market studies were carried out to determine
the economic potential of the three areas. The
studies consisted of:
